Entry.1: Went to Sydney to join Expeditionery Force.
Entry.2: Passed Medical Examination at Victoria Barracks and went to Liverpool and was put into "M" Coy, in the Depot under Lieut. Hourn.
Entry.3: Issued with trousers, cap and great coat.
Entry.4:
Saw Harry and Frank Proctor

24 March

5th on a route March

25 March

5th on duty. Sham fight between 4th and
Entry.6: Went into Liverpool field hospital with measles.
Entry.8: Taken out to isolation hospital in Red X Waggon
Entry.10: In hospital. Trooper Mulhollen died from pneunomia.
Entry.11: Discharged from hospital. Granted 7 days sick leave. Transferred from
Entry.13: Batt. to G.I. Company. Depot. Arrive home Saturday morning. Dad came from Narraburra Sat. Evening.
Entry.14: Spend a day in Sydney with mother.
Entry.15: Ride to "Cross Hill" on the bike.
Entry.16: Dad went back to Narraburra. Hector got here at 3 p.m.
Entry.17: Hector went back to "Allandale". 5th Reinforcements of the 13 Battalion sail for Egypt.
Entry.20: G.I. on duty. I get dungarees and white hat and start squad drill.
Entry.21: "G" on duty. Am on river picket with Heath and Hale.
Entry.22: Scale Church parade with Corp. Creft.
Entry.24: Am on cooks fatigue with Hall and Taylor.
Entry.27: Issued with rifle 12202. No. of my rifles 1037, 18693, 28782, 4479, HV rifles issued at Ishmalia, 2886, 28934.
Entry.28: Went on route march through City.
Entry.29: I take quarter guard for a mate who went on leave.
Entry.32: Issued with uniform and split up into the company.
Entry.35: Company for duty. Inoculation. Harman, Andrews, Woodward and I on the officers mess.
Entry.36: Granted final leave. Saw Aunt Fan and Harry Proctor at Strathfield.
Entry.37: Arrive home. Saw Mrs. Lawler. Mother and I spend evening at Mr. West’s.
Entry.38: Mother and I went to Mrs. Lawlers.
Entry.39: Father arrived here at 4 p.m. I rang up Nance and asked her to meet me at Coota. Leave Stock for camp.
Entry.40: Arrive at camp. Saw Harry Proctor. Scale into Sydney.
Entry.41: No parade, wet day. Scale into Sydney with Harry Proctor.
Entry.42: Platoon drill. Get my photo taken.
Entry.43: No Church parade. Coy. on duty. Issued with second uniform. I am on as Batt. orderly till 10 p.m.
Entry.44: Get an issue of underclothes and boots. I go aboard the troop ship with the advance guard. Lieut. Shawe and Serg. Miller in charge of Advance party.
Entry.45: Aboard. Troop ship towed into Woolloomooloo. Draw blankets and hammocks for "A" Coy.
Entry.46: Sail at 5 p.m. after a great send-off.
Entry.47: Receive two letters from home. Issued with shoes.
Entry.48: Smooth sea. Pass a large school of dolphins.
Entry.53: See the last of Australian coast. Grand concert in which "Blue" Tindall sang:- "Ammunition Van". Rifle drill and lecture on visual training.
Entry.54: Parade in full marching order. Bayonet drill. Issued with pay books and identity discs. Weather calm and warm.
Entry.55: Sports & concert. Tug-or-war between "D" and "B" D1. See a large black fish. Heavy swell on. Ragtime fight between "Spud" Murphy and McGregor.
Entry.56: Fire alarm. Stand-to boats. Gunners practice with 4" guns.
Entry.57: Church parade on boat deck, church service on well deck. Squally weather.
Entry.58: Coy. on duty, am with a fatigue party hauling spuds out of the hold. See a shoal of flying fish. Dead calm and sultery. Boxing match between Gorpy v Dawson. Brown v Brown and a Keystone fight between "Spud" Murphy & MacGregor. Blue Tindall sang "Amunition Van" etc.
Entry.59: Steamer stops for gun practice. Pass Cocos Island. Write home.
Entry.61: Overhaul the troop ship "Sontay". The "Sontay" left Sydney 2 days before us with a load of French Reservists.
Entry.62: Parade in full marching order. Cross the "Line". Sports & a concert.
Entry.63: 222 miles from Colombo. "A" Coy. for duty. Am on as deck sweeper.
Entry.64: Coaling at Colombo. Route march through the town. Sail at 8 p.m.
Entry.65: See the most Southern point of India at 8 a.m. Coast in sight all day. Rifle drill and lectures.
Entry.68: Kings birthday. No Parade. Write home.
Entry.70: Pass the Island of Socotra. Consert in aid of Pte. Manning’s widow.
Entry.72: In Red Sea. Pass a number of small islands.
Entry.73: Coy. for duty. Am on deck guard. Early morning parade with tunics and side arms.
Entry.74: Arrive at Suez at 2 AM. Early morning parade in full dress.
Entry.75: Disembark & entrain for Cairo. Detrain at Zeatoun and march to Heliopolis arriving there at 10 p.m. Have a drink of water for tea, lie down in the dirt and go to sleep.
Entry.76: Coy for duty. Am on guard. See the 5th of the
Entry.77: and some of my old friends.
Entry.78: Got into Heliopolis & take a tram for Cairo.
Entry.79: Coy pitching tents. Scale into Cairo.
Entry.81: artill. (false alarm). Corp B & I sick.
Entry.84: "A" Company digging trenches. Am on as mess orderly.
Entry.85: Full marching order parade and kit inspection.
Entry.86: Trench digging and extended order work. Bayonet charge.
Entry.87: "A" Coy on duty. Am on guard at the Brigade orderly room. Lieut. Gombert Commander of the guard.
Entry.88: Come off guard in the evening. 3 & 4 Platoons apposed in extended order work.
Entry.89: Am Sick. Take french leave and go into Cairo.
Entry.90: 1, 2, & 3 Platoons go to the range for rifle shooting. 4 Platoon granted leave for Cairo. We go and see the Pyrimids and had a spin round Cairo in a motor with Sergeant Pulling & corp. Bradford arriving back home at 9 p.m.
Entry.92: Issued with Kahki shorts & shirts. Go to the range for rifle shooting. Fire 10 rounds in the "grouping".
Entry.94: Finish all the ranges. I score 105 points. "A" Coy. marches home to Heliopolis.
Entry.95: See "Tiny Ryan". The 7 Brigade arrive at Abbasia Barracks.
Entry.96: Am sick. Go on guard at 7-12 PM. Sergeant Robertson & Corp. Perrol over guard.
Entry.97: Guard dismissed at 8 AM. Go into Cairo with 4 mates. We see the zoo etc. & arrive home at 9 PM. Webb, O’Hara, Taylor.
Entry.98: No. 2 Platoon sent on picket duty in Cairo. 27 Batt. arrive.
Entry.99: "A" Coy. on duty. Have a yarn with "Tiny" Ryan of the 13th Batt.
Entry.100: Route march through Heliopolis & out into the desert. 5th of the 13th Battalion leave for the front. "A" Coy. digging trenches under Lieut. Pye.
Entry.101: "A" Coy. on duty. Address by Colonel Unsworth in the Y.M.C.A.
Entry.102: "D" Coy. goes to the rifle range.
Entry.104: "A" Coy. on duty. Am on guard. Receive letter from home dated June 7th.
Entry.105: Came off guard & go on an 8 mile route march through Heliopolis to the Tower.
Entry.106: Sharp shooters leave for the range. Trench digging & rearguard action.
Entry.107: Practice in advance guard and outposts. Lecture on Company in the attack by Capt. Beiers. Route march half way to Zeatoun and back through Abbassia Barracks & Heliopolis.
Entry.108: Company in the attack & trench digging, receive pay & write home.
Entry.109: Route march to the Tower. Pitching tents for the 18th Batt.
Entry.110: 27th Batt. 6th Brigade leave for Abbassia to make room for the 19 Batt. Spend the afternoon writing home. Try to get into the M.G. Section.
Entry.111: Church parade. Take a trip to Cairo by train through Zeatoun. Go into Heliopolis, with Corp. Bradford.
Entry.112: 6 to 9 Practice in Coy in attack. 11 to 12 Lecture on our position in the Dardanelles. "A" on duty. 6th of the 13th arrive at Zeatoun. Am sick & miss the afternoon parade.
Entry.113: Practice for field firing on the range. Lecture by Captain Smith on the application of the first field dressing. Receive letters & paper from home. Go into Heliopolis with P Taylor to the American Mission. Advance guard of the 18th arrive.
Entry.115:
Return to camp after all night march. Thurs. evening A & B Coys go to the Abbassia range for field firing.

23 July 

Finish field practice and return to camp. 500 of the 18th turn up.
Entry.116: 18th & 19th in camp at Heliopolis. C & D Coys return from Abbassia.
Entry.119: On Guard till 12 o’clock. 20 Batt arrive.
Entry.121: Pay day. Receive mail from home.
Entry.122: Field firing with blanks. Pte. Harman out of hospital.
Entry.123: No afternoon parade. All night route march.
Entry.124: Sham fight with blanks. Receive letter from Aunt Fan. Battle in the "Wassa".
Entry.125: Church parade. Go into Heliopolis. Brawl in Pyrimid Hotel. 17th Batt sent into Cairo on picket duty.
Entry.126: Receive letter from home. 17th on a night march from 7 till 1 AM. Lose the bolt of my Rifle. "Dad" Higgins throws his rifle to blazes and falls out.
Entry.127: Kit inspection. Hand in my rifle. Route march through Zeatoun. "17" Batt ordered to the Citadel in Cairo.
Entry.128: "A" on Brigade duty. I am on Quarter-masters fatigue. Get a new bolt for my rifle.
Entry.129: Write home. "A" & "B" Coys. digging trenches. No. 4 Platoon dig themselves in with entrenching tools. Men for Engineers taken out of the Batt.
Entry.130: Colonel Holmes lectures 5th Brigade about the disgrace of the "Battle of the Wassa".
Entry.131: out at 9PM for an all night march. 15th section remain behind for guard.
Entry.132: No. 15 Section on perimeter guard. Serg. Allan, Corp. Wolf over guard.
Entry.133: Trench digging and Coy in attack. Pay day.
Entry.134: Company drill. Bayonet fighting and Batt. drill.
Entry.135: 17 Batt. march to the Citadel & back to Heliopolis.
Entry.136: Kit inspection and muster parade. Foot inspection.
Entry.137: 1st of the 17th come from Zeatoun and are drafted into the 17th Batt. The officers, machine gunners and signalers return from the school at Zeatoun. 15th Section go on guard at 7-10 PM. Receive letter from mother (dated July 9th) and Lou. Also 1 pair of sox and Coota papers. "B", "C" & "D" Coys go on night march.
Entry.138: 5 Brigade receive pay. 15 Section dismount guard at 12.30 P.M. Write my last letter from Heliopolis. Hand in pith helmet. Issued with colours.
Entry.139: Pack kit & prepare to leave camp at 7.30 PM. Have our last church parade in Egypt. 17th Fall in at 7.30 PM. March to Zeatoun and entrain for Alexandria.
Entry.140: Arrive at Alexandria at 2.30 AM. No. 4 platoon picked out for loading baggage. Sail at 6 p.m. Muster parade in full pack.
Entry.141: Life belt parade. Pass a British submarine.
Entry.142:
Cranstone & I on as Mess Orderlies. At Lemnos Is. Strike Clarry Le Suer of Cootamundra.

19 August 

Tranship from the Alaunia to two small steamers and leave Lemnos for Galipoli. Issued with ammunition 200 Round.

20 August 

Land at Anzac & waiting in Rest Gully to be sent into the firing line. 17th & 18th leave rest gully at dark. March up in rear of firing line on the left. I sleep in a dugout with a New Zealander. Marten of 3 Pla. wounded.

21 August 

Have breakfast with the New Zealanders. We march up behind the firing line on the left. Expecting a big advance against Hill 971. Pte Vanstone. Hit Shrapnel. Well, we are preparing for a bayonet charge.

22 August 

"18"th in action lose 600 men. "C" & "D" Coys. sent into the firing line to relieve 13 Batt. "17"th in a gully in rear of the 16th.

23 August 

See Pte Styles of 13 Batt. Am on guard. A & B Coys of 17 ordered into the firing line with the 13th.

24 August 

We go into the trenches of the 13th Batt. I have dinner with 3 of my old mates of the 5th of the 13th. See Brierly & Clark.

25 August 

Am on well fatigue with Harman in the valley behind our firing line. Our duty is to draw water out of a 40 ft. well for the 17th Batt.

26 August 

Harman and I get the water supply job for good. See Pte Lewis & Hickson.

27 August 

Harman & I brave the shapnel & go down to the beach for a swim. Big advance on the left by the 13th, 15th, 17th & 18th Batts. 4 Platoons of "A"
Entry.143: held in reserve. Lieut Pye & Corp. Wolf wounded. Lieut Gombert & Serg. Robertson killed.
Entry.145: No. 4 in the trenches. Some of the men in the charge turn up for rations. Lance Corp. Bennet give us a vivid account of the charge.
Entry.146: Taube flies over and drops 3 bombs misses us by a ½ mile. The Turks drop plenty of shrapnel round us, some of it comes within 3 yds. of us. Harman & I go into the trenches at 7 PM.
Entry.147: Come out of the trenches at 7 AM. Sgt. Chisolm wounded. 1 Platoon of the Essex wiped out by shrapnel in Reserve Gully.
Entry.148: Am on sniping. "A" Coy relieved by the Essex. Leave at 7 A.M. for Reserve Gully.
Entry.149: Rest in Reserve Gully. Move off at dark to Monash Gully on the right.
Entry.150: 17th in Monash Gully,. "A" Coy move into the firing line at Quinns Post. Harman & I in the trenches, together with the 3rd Light Horse.
Entry.151: Relieved at 1 AM. At midnight the 3 ALH leave us to it & march back to relieve the Essex.
Entry.152:
Harman & I go down to Anzac for a swim. Egan & McTague killed with their own bomb. Groom wounded. Have 
bread
 for tea.
Entry.153:
I join the bomb throwing and go into the bomb trench to relieve Durand & Materson. Have the best dinner since we landed 
on the peninsula. Roast beef & bread.
Entry.154: Bomb throwing from 6 AM to 12 and from 6 PM to 12 midnight. We have a bit of a rally at 12, turks cut down the wire netting with the machine gun & threw in 3 bombs none of which do any damage. Durand & I send back a dozen in return.
Entry.155: Breakfast on tea & a desert spoon of rum & go into the trenches at 6 AM. Turks complete their barbed wire entanglement.
Entry.156: Receive mail and a letter from Lou. Issued with bread and syrup, ½ a loaf per man, & 3 tins among 18 men.
Entry.157: Issued with rum before going into the trenches at 6 AM. Mack & Day have a narrow shave from Turks bombs. We have a big rally 9 PM firing 5 rounds rapid & then yelling rattling the bayonets as if we were charging. The Turks replyed with a heavy fire that lasted ½ an hour.
Entry.158: Am out of the trenches for a spell. Bully beef stew & flies for breakfast. Dinner: beef & biscuits. Tea: a slice of bacon fat and a biscuit.
Entry.159: Rum issued, wounded in the neck with glass while looking through a perescope. Stew, biscuits & tea for breakfast & dinner & 1 pancake 4" dia. for tea. The doctor puts me off duty for a few days on account of my wound. Receive 2 letters from mother dated July 14 & July 23rd.
Entry.160: Go on duty at 6 PM. Write home.
Entry.161: Off duty – Sick. Stevenson wounded with bomb. Go on duty at 6 PM in the bomb trench.
Entry.163: Have some rain which makes it very unpleasant.
Entry.164:
Mail in. Receive letter from mother. Lieut. Sheppard wounded by a bomb thrown from the Turks trench. The Turks throw a packet of tobacco and cigarette papers. I enjoy a very pleasant smoke out of it. Heavy demonstration at 10 PM. Craig wounded with a bomb. Garland Gun explodes. Killed one and wounded two more.

17 Sept. 

Have a day out of the trench and write home. 2nd Rein. of the
Entry.165:
arrive by the 
Kingtonian
 B.15 Kingstonian from Egypt.
Entry.166:
The Turks send us plenty of bombs and give us a 
lively time
. Turks open heavy fire on Courtanays & Popes Hill at 5 PM. Captain Lonsdale wounded with a Turks bombs.
Entry.167: The Turks send in plenty of bombs. Pte. Hugo wounded. Mail in.
Entry.168: "B" Coy. relieve "A" Coy. in the trenches.
Entry.170: Taken aboard Hospital ship. Capt. Colwell comes down to Anzac to see me off.
Entry.171: Sail from Anzac at 9 AM for Lemnos arriving there at 8 PM.
Entry.172: Tranship from Glenart Castle to the Grampian.
Entry.174: In the harbour at Malta at 8 AM.
Entry.175: Put on 100 Wounded and start coaling.
Entry.178: P.M. We stop at Gibralta until 10 P.M.
Entry.180: Pick up the escort of 2 destroyers.
Entry.181: Stop off Plymouth at 4 AM. 8 AM come into the harbour and tie up at the wharf opposite the ‘Alaunica’ and the ‘Caimania’. Disembark and entrain for Bristol. Leave Plymouth at 1 PM & arrive in Bristol at 5 PM after a very pleasant journey.
Entry.183: In bed with a bad headache.
Entry.185: Am well of interic and transferred to ward 16.
Entry.186: I am taken out to tea with 20 other Australians. After seeing the zoo we have tea in a gentleman’s house.
Entry.187: A visitor comes to see me. Am in bed. Have a sleepless night.
Entry.189: Go for a spin in a car to Bristol Channel.
Entry.191: The "General" and I go to Bristol on Pass.
Entry.192: I say goodbye to Southmead Hospital and go to Epsom.
Entry.193: 1916 – Diary continued after 3 months in Hospital & Convalescent
Entry.196: and transfer to the "Ivernia" from the "Olympic". Sail for Alexandria
Entry.199: Entrain for Cairo at 12 noon in cattle trucks. Journey takes 7 hours. We amuse ourselves by pelting the niggers with cactus leaves which we picked at the side of the line.
Entry.201: to Cairo & entrain for Ishmalia. Bivwack for two days at Moasca.
Entry.202: The "17" Batt. came in from the desert & we rejoin them.
Entry.205: We pass the Island of Malta. See the coast of France on the night of
Entry.207: Land at Marceilles and entrain for Rouen.
Entry.209: Detrain at Tiene and billeted in the village. 40 of us sleep in a barn.
Entry.210:
Roy Edwards, Kelly & I on guard on bridge of Tienne.

Tienne is about 30 miles from the firing line. We can hear the big guns & see the search lights at night. I am guard on the bridge in the wet and cold.
Entry.211: We have been having some fine weather the last week. Yesterday we marched 10 miles as drill & today we had a very severe march. The rumblings of the big guns in the north continuously.
Entry.212: I received a letter from home dated
Entry.213: No. 4 Platoon is for duty. We have a route march and a liquid fire demonstration, showing how the enemy hose burning oil at our trenches. We hand in our black bags and get ready to move into the firing line.
Entry.215: We are resting behind the firing line at Armentieres. We left Thunnes 2 days ago. Were inspected by General Joffre at the beginning of the march.
Entry.218: We have been in the trenches, 3 days. It rained all the first two days but today is fine giving us a chance to dry our clothes. Our duty is in the supports. We also do guard at night and carrying the Coys rations. This is a quiet firing line with very little rifle shooting. The enemy is 500 yds. away. We have been shelled a bit today, 1 killed, & 2 wounded.
Entry.220: We are relieved by the 19th and march out at dark to billets in Armentiers.
Entry.221: Resting in the billets. 1 Fine day.
Entry.222: On fatigue in the supports in the wet.
Entry.223: Wet day. Get a warm bath and change of underclothes.
Entry.224: Move into the trenches, more rain. Had trouble getting a dug out – finally got one with another individual – very comfortable – a good deal of shelling during the afternoon. Spent nearly all night on fatigue – intend going in for heavy weight lifting when the war is over. Got to bed, wet through at 3 AM tired out.
Entry.225: Turned out for stand-to at 3.45 AM. Bed again at 5 AM. Slept long enough to miss breakfast. Fine day, tried to dry all wet clothes etc. Loafed all day till stand-to at 6.40 PM. fatigue from 7 P.M. to 2 AM carrying timber – up to our knees in slush.
Entry.226: Stand to at 3.45. Get into bed at 5 AM and sleep till dinner time. Raining again, the enemy artillary has been busy all day. A shell exploded 10 yds from me and my friend peppering us with mud clods. This section of the trench has earned its name "Whiz Bang Avenue". Start fatigue at 8 P.M. Finish about 3 AM. Stand to 3.40. Bed at 5 AM.
Entry.227: Miserable wet day. No opportunity to dry our wet clothes. Tried in vain to sleep all day. Fatigue at 7 P.M. finish at 3.30 a.m. Fair sleep but terribly wet & cold.
Entry.228: Go out of the trenches today. It is, strange to say, a fine day too. We badly wanted to dry our clothes but have to carry wet blankets .
Entry.229: Get up at 3 a.m. Move into the trenches at "Jocks Joy" to do engineers fatigue – that is pumping water out of the trenches and putting down new foot boards. We move out at 2 PM covered with mud and very tired. High explosive shells drop very close to us wounding several men on the left of where we are working.
Entry.230:
– Anzac Day. 

Fall in at 9 AM with 3 others out of the Platoon for bombing instruction. Bathing parade in the afternoon. When getting to our billets after 4 days in the trenches we are marched in batches of 50 to an old dye works 5 miles behind the firing line. I enjoy a hot bath and change of underclothes. As we are marching back the Germans shell "A" Coys billet. One shell strikes the farm house setting it on fire instantly. 214 shells fall on the house and the paddock behind it.
Entry.231: Fine. No. 4 on guard and fatigues. Bombers return to billets for instruction. Have a look at the remains of "Coys" billet – Enemy shell Armentiers – we retaliate vigoriously.
Entry.232: Came into the trenches at about 3 A.M. with the Grenadiers Division. During the evening our artillary showed "Fritz" the correct way to bombard the trenches. Fritz sent tried to show what he had learned and returned a shower of iron rations which we didn’t appreciate. Also had a gas alarm. No casualties.
Entry.233: Am observing from 12.30 a.m. to 1 a.m. Stand-to from 3.30 to 4.30 A.M. Fine day.
Entry.234:
Beautiful day. Very quiet until 4 p.m. Have been asleep on the fire step since dinner time. 

One of our planes is up and Fritz’s shrapnell is bursting above and below but never very close to him. 

The ‘Coal Boxes’ are going over head with a sound like the steam out of a ‘loco’, and exploding about a mile behind our lines. Fritz is evidently feeling for our artillary – or fallowing a paddock for next year.

Am on watch from 9.30 to 11 p.m. Two patrols of 3 men each are out from "A" and "B" Companys till 11 p.m. examining the barbed wire etc. in "no mans land". The enemy on right front open fire about 9.30 p.m. and we thinking that perhaps they had sighted our patrols, sood on the fire step and returned the fire – aiming at their flashes to keep their heads down and give our men a chance to get back. 

3 or 4 bombs go off in Fritz’s trench and we are wondering who is throwing them. After being relieved I lie down on the bottom of the trench and sleep to be awakened an hour later to be prepared for a gas attack as there is a light breeze from the German lines. 

The patrols ¾ of an hour late without any losses.
Entry.235:
The usual "stand-to" at daylight then a sleep until 8 a.m., wake to find 3 letters from home dated March 11th. 

Fritz is dropping a few "coal boxes" on Bois-Grenier. There are no fires as everything inflamable has been burned by previous bombardments. 

Learn that the patrols returned safely after a bit of excitment. When about 50 yards in front of our own parapet they blundered into a water hole and had to stay there as Fritz heard them and opened fire with rifle and machine gun. After an hour the fire died down and they were able to return. The bombing was done by some of the
Entry.237:
Sentry from 12.30 to 2 a.m. Quiet night. Wake at 8 a.m. to find Fritz shelling two of our ‘planes – it would be better to say "firing at them – directly over head. The falling shrapnel is hissing all around. Our planes are more cheeky than the Taubs and at times come almost within range of the enemy.

At 9 a.m. a "Taub" appears about a mile up. I empty my magazine at it but am asked by my mates if I am trying to work my head to be sent home for insanity.
Entry.238: Relieved by 19th at 3.30 p.m. (Fritz still busy with artillary). Move out of the trenches at dark to our billets. Turn in dead tired after a mile march in full pack.
Entry.239: Rise at 9 AM and go to Bois Grenier bombing school for a course of bombing. Rest of No. 4 go into trenches on fatigue. Ptd. Whatson Killed, Mitchell wounded at Tramway Avenue.
Entry.240: Lovely day. Brigade bomb school ½ mile from Erymingham.
Entry.241: Quiet all day. Return from bomb school at 4 PM. German artillary opens out on the trench held by the
Entry.242: Batt. at 6.30 p.m. A strong patrol attacks the with grenades but is held back by the 20th.
Entry.243: Resting all day in the billets after "standing-to" all night in the
Entry.244: line – Grenadiers fall in at 8 p.m. and march to "B" Coys Billet armed to the teeth with bombs. Sleep there in our clothes till "stand-to" as we expected Fritz to attack.
Entry.245: Wet day. We are resting in Billets in Armentiers. Firing line terribly quiet.
Entry.246: Anniversary of the day we sailed from Aust. We go into the trenches at 8 P.M.
Entry.247: The first fine day since we have been in the trenches. German artillary shelling the
Entry.248: with high explosives. Gas alarm at sunset. We "Stand-to" with helmets ready. Stayed down for 30 seconds out over the parapet. Lieut. Pye killed. Germans open heavy fire at 10 P.M.
Entry.249: Fine day. Fairly quiet. Trenches inspected by General Birdwood & General Holmes. Gas alarm at Sunset.
Entry.250: Fine day very quiet. Receive a letter from home. Write 3. Go to the "College".
Entry.251: Fritz shelling "Bois Grenier". Our trench mortors busy on the left. "Stand to" till 10 p.m. German planes up we are ordered to put out all lights. Germans put a few shells.
Entry.252: Rifle and gas. We give Fritz a few shells. He retaliates by shelling "B" Coys trench with schrapnel and high explosives making things very lively. A machine gun possee was blown to pieces. We’re 9 to 12 noon. Explosions in Fritz’s trench on the right. Evidently an accident.
Entry.253: Stand to arms at 1 A.M. as we get word of a big attack on the right. Stand down at 3 AM and turn in tired out and sleep till dinner time. Weather like a storm. Artillary fairly busy. A Whiz-bang is dropped in front of our parapet. Prepare to move out but are ordered to stay in another night to our sorrow.
Entry.254: "Stand-to" at 2.15 AM. Our trench mortars on the left stir Fritz up till stand down. At 2 P.M. Fritz is dropping high explosives all along our line. We are feeling uncomfortable. After a while Fritz stops and our guns start. We are preparing to move out of the trenches, move out at 8 P.M. through "Tramway Avenue" to our billets in Armentiers. Engineers working on the supports and the new avenue.
Entry.255: Resting in Billets. We go down and get a well earned bath and a change of under clothes. Transfer from the bombers to the Platoon. Spend the rest of the day wandering about Armentiers. Am feeling depressed – it starts to rain making me worse in spirits. Kelly & Abbot granted leave for England.
Entry.256: Wet day. We receive pay. fatigue all night. Return in the morning tired and damp.
Entry.257: "A" Coy. on fatigue in "Tramway Avenue". Work all night on the pick and shovel and filling sand bags. Rifle and machine gun bullets come fairly close. Fritz starts shelling 7th Brigade at 3.30 a.m.
Entry.258: Wake up to find an English mail waiting for me. Go to Armentiers for dinner. Sleep all the afternoon.
Entry.259: Fine day very quiet. Detailed for night fatigue.
Entry.260: Returning to billets tired out. Our Field pieces open out at 2 A.M. Fritz shells "B" Coy. billets.
Entry.264:
Bat. 5th F.A. shelled and silenced. Planes lands inside the German lines. Our captive baloon breaks adrift. See two men come down in parachutes. As we are marching up to the firing line we are shelled – 3 casualties.

June 2

Fall in at 8 p.m. Go into the supports on fatigue.
Entry.265: Return home at 2.30 A.M. Bombardment on the right – gas alarm. Enter the trenches at 8 P.M. Heavy bombardment on the left. Lieut – brings along news of the navy battle.
Entry.266: Artillary activity. Enemy bombard two salients heavily.
Entry.267: Wet day. Very quiet. We are on fatigue in firing line. "Stand-to" all night as we are expecting the 27th Batt. to raid the German trenches on the left.
